metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: Leaf area index of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Sidaoqiao in the downstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 24 to July 18 in 2022. The site was located in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 870 m. There are 1 observation samples, around Sidaoqiao superstation (101.1374E, 42.0012N), which is about 30m×30m in size. Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather leaf area index (LAI) measurements in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for gathering leaf area index (LAI) measurements in arid regions involves using the LAINet wireless sensor network, which collects light data automatically from multiple nodes at specific intervals. These data are processed through various levels to calculate daily LAI, identify and fill invalid values, and apply a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-related variations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting long-term data in oasis-desert ecosystems is dealing with the ecological degradation crises such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins along the Silk Road.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset containing energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data from oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which includes energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012. This dataset is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center and includes additional hydrometeorological and vegetation/soil parameters.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Leaf Area Index (LAI)' in the context of environmental monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Leaf Area Index (LAI) is a measure of leaf coverage in a given area, representing the total leaf area per unit ground surface area. In environmental monitoring, it is used to assess vegetation density, health, and its influence on energy, water, and carbon exchanges.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'eddy covariance system' in the context of data collection for arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a micrometeorological technique used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the boundary layer, typically for variables such as carbon dioxide, water vapor, and energy. It is particularly useful in arid regions for understanding exchanges between the land surface and the atmosphere.

Definition.Question: What does 'scintillometer' refer to in the data collection methods for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: A scintillometer is an instrument used to measure the turbulence in the air, which affects the propagation of light, and is employed in data collection to determine heat fluxes across land surfaces. In oasis–desert ecosystems, it helps quantify the energy exchanges critical for understanding ecological stability.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing steps between leaf area index datasets and datasets involving hydrometeorology and flux measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Leaf area index datasets undergo processing involving daily calculations, invalid value identification, and averaging to mitigate weather influence, whereas datasets involving hydrometeorology and flux measurements follow procedures that include data collection, processing, and quality control, integrating various parameters such as radiation and soil characteristics for comprehensive understanding.

Interpretation.Question: What might be inferred about the interaction between oasis–desert systems and the global carbon cycle from long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data?
Interpretation.Answer: It can be inferred that oasis–desert areas, particularly those in semiarid regions, may act as carbon sinks. This suggests their potential significant impact on the carbon balance of arid regions and their increasing role within the global carbon cycle.

Interpretation.Question: How do data collection techniques, such as those using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, help in understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: These techniques allow for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are crucial for a quantitative understanding of the interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems. They provide detailed insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes, aiding in the maintenance of ecological stability and socio-economic development in these areas.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection and environmental monitoring can be inferred from the ecological degradation crises faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include monitoring the drying of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues highlight the need for robust data collection and monitoring techniques to address ecological degradation and maintain ecological security.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to process and refine raw observational data to ensure accuracy and reliability in the context of leaf area index measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the context of leaf area index measurements, the raw observational data, initially collected as daily and hourly light data at each node (Level0), is processed using LAINet software to calculate daily LAI for each node (Level1). This involves identifying and filling invalid values and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate the effects of weather variation on LAI calculations (Level2). For areas with multiple LAINet nodes, the mean of the nodes is used as the final observation value for the subregion (Level3).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can long-term observational datasets be structured to include diverse environmental parameters in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems can include a variety of environmental parameters by collecting data on energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters. This data is often acquired through instruments like eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations that record various metrics such as radiation, soil heat flux, temperature gradients, wind profiles, and groundwater table data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in establishing a comprehensive observational network for studying land surface processes in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Establishing a comprehensive observational network for studying land surface processes in arid regions involves setting up multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations, including superstations and ordinary stations. The network should facilitate the collection of data on energy, water vapor, carbon exchange, and auxiliary information such as hydrometeorological variables, soil parameters, and vegetation characteristics. Data collection, processing, quality control, and archiving procedures are crucial to ensure data reliability and accessibility, as exemplified by the datasets available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Enablement.Question: What technologies or instruments are utilized to enable the accurate and efficient collection of leaf area index data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The leaf area index data is collected using a wireless sensor network called LAINet, which captures light exposure data at various nodes. The network automates data acquisition, enabling efficient and accurate daily monitoring of leaf area index in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw observational data into usable datasets for analyzing oasis–desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques involve several steps, including automated data acquisition, daily calculation of leaf area index, identification and filling of invalid values, and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-related variations. This processing transforms raw data into a refined dataset that can be used to analyze interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or strategies enable the successful establishment and operation of long-term observational stations in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Enablement.Answer: Successful establishment and operation of long-term observational stations are enabled by carefully selecting sites in strategic locations such as the middle and lower reaches of river basins, leveraging advanced instruments like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, and employing comprehensive data collection methods that capture energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, along with supporting hydrometeorological and vegetation data.

Expectation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize interactions and protect ecological stability. However, challenges such as ecological environment degradation in arid regions and the need for long-term observations might affect the completeness of data on these interactions.

Expectation.Question: Why could anticipated outcomes of energy exchange studies in arid regions differ from actual results?
Expectation.Answer: The actual results might differ due to the complex nature of the oasis–desert systems, which require a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development. The crisis of ecological degradation, such as river and lake drying, could also lead to discrepancies between expected and actual outcomes.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the data collection methods used in monitoring leaf area index in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, such as the use of LAINet systems, which involve wireless sensor networks for leaf area index observations, are effective in providing detailed and continuous data. These methods allow for daily measurements and use processing techniques like moving averages to mitigate weather-related variations, thereby enhancing the reliability of the data.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges in maintaining the quality and consistency of long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include environmental degradation issues like drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms that may impact data collection. Additionally, maintaining consistent data quality over long periods requires robust processing and quality control measures to handle factors such as equipment malfunctions and environmental changes.

Judgmental.Question: How might future technological advancements improve the data collection and processing techniques for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Future advancements could enhance data collection and processing through improved sensor technology, more sophisticated data processing algorithms, and better integration of remote sensing with ground observations. This could lead to higher accuracy and resolution in monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, ultimately supporting more effective ecological management and policy-making.

Assertion.Answer: The data collection method involves using LAINet software to process raw data by calculating daily LAI at each node, identifying and filling invalid values, and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate the impact of weather changes on LAI calculations, resulting in a more stable and reliable dataset.

Assertion.Answer: Integrating both natural and artificial systems allows for a comprehensive understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges by observing long-term fluxes and auxiliary data, which are crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development in these regions.

Assertion.Answer: Synthesizing data from different environmental parameters, such as energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes along with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data from multiple stations, provides a quantitative understanding of the key exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is critical for achieving sustainable development goals and maintaining ecological balance.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection techniques used for observing leaf area index and other ecological parameters in arid and semiarid regions, emphasizing the technological and methodological aspects.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using a wireless sensor network (LAINet) for obtaining leaf area index (LAI) data. The network captures light exposure data automatically at each node hourly, which is then processed using specialized software to calculate daily LAI values. These observations are further refined through invalid value identification, filling, and a 7-day sliding average to mitigate the influence of weather changes. Additionally, long-term datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, collected via an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, supplemented by hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be utilized for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, and suggest strategies for dataset expansion or refinement.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, collected from a network of 11 stations since 2012. These datasets are freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center and include auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Strategies for dataset expansion or refinement could involve increasing the number and distribution of observation stations, integrating remote sensing data for broader spatial coverage, and enhancing data processing techniques to improve accuracy and reliability.
